image.altText: Four people on surf boards bobbing in the ocean, beneath a pale blue sky with clouds

items.synopsis: Four Australians and two Indonesian crew whose boat went missing during a surf trip off the coast of Aceh have been found alive after several days at sea, while one crew member is still missing.

title.children: Australians found 'bobbing around on their surf boards' after going missing in Indonesia

items.synopsis: Canberra man Muhammad Arif is charged with allegedly claiming to have explosives on board a Malaysia Airlines flight from Sydney to Kuala Lumpur yesterday.

title.children: 'Confused': Man accused of making explosives threat on Sydney flight doesn't understand charges, court told

image.altText: police on a plane after an incident

items.synopsis: Aviation and security experts weigh in on how in-flight threats of violence are handled, and whose jurisdiction it is to respond.

title.children: 'Our slightest female crew could take down someone quite large': How threatening behaviour on planes is dealt with

image.altText: Donald Trump stands at a microphone. He is wearing a blue suit and red tie and pictured against a dark background.

items.synopsis: The former US president is indicted over alleged attempts to meddle with the 2020 election results in Georgia. He and 18 allies face a racketeering charge that carries mandatory prison time.

title.children: Donald Trump's indictment in Georgia could feature some 'smoking guns'. Here's what we know about the case

image.altText: A supermarket checkout worker

items.synopsis: Wall Street gains and profit reporting season continues in Australia. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wages data, RBA minutes to give indicator of next steps in interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Citi economists Joshua Williamson and Faraz Syed say they think the slight decline in annual wages growth we've seen in the June quarter will only be temporary. They think it was the result of temporary seasonal softness in retail, accommodation and food, and a temporary "air pocket" in public education, administration and safety. So, should we expect wages to pick up again? They think so. " Wage costs will accelerate further from here, driven by very low unemployment lifting individual and enterprise agreements and higher award and minimum wage gains across the public and private sectors," they said. "But whatever the driver, wage gains are not being met with productivity gains, meaning unit labour costs will continue to rise, eventually forcing a reluctant RBA to lift official interest rates further. " We continue to expect a peak of 4.6% before the RBA's hiking cycle is complete." The cash rate target is currently 4.1%. So, they think the RBA will lift interest rates by another 0.5 percentage points from here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Expect wages to pick up again, with more rate rises to come?

children.content: Citi economists Joshua Williamson and Faraz Syed say they think the slight decline in annual wages growth we've seen in the June quarter will only be
temporary
They think it was the result of temporary seasonal softness in retail, accommodation and food, and a temporary "air pocket" in public education, administration and safety.
So, should we expect wages to pick up again? They think so.
Wage costs will accelerate further from here
, driven by very low unemployment lifting individual and enterprise agreements and higher award and minimum wage gains across the public and private sectors," they said.

"But whatever the driver, wage gains are not being met with productivity gains, meaning unit labour costs will continue to rise, eventually forcing a reluctant RBA to lift official interest rates further.
We continue to expect a peak of 4.6%
before the RBA's hiking cycle is complete."
The cash rate target is currently 4.1%.
So, they think the RBA will lift interest rates by another 0.5 percentage points from here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers, and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke, have issued a joint statement about the June quarter wages data. To recap, wages grew by 0.8 per cent in the June quarter, and they're now increasing at an annual pace of 3.6 per cent (down slightly from 3.7 per cent in March). Meanwhile, headline inflation grew by 0.8 per cent in the June quarter, down from 1.4 per cent in the March quarter. So, the quarterly rate of growth in wages and inflation is now the same, if for a brief moment. Dr Chalmers and Mr Burke have picked up on that fact, while noting that the rate of growth in real wages is probably still a while away. " This is the first time in three years that quarterly wages have kept up with inflation - and much better than the fall of 1.5 per cent in the March quarter 2022," they said. "While there will be volatility in the next few quarters, Treasury expects annual real wages to return to growth in early 2024 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer Jim Chalmers welcomes wage data

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers, and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke, have issued a joint statement about the June quarter wages data.
To recap,
wages grew by 0.8 per cent in the June quarter
, and they're now increasing at an annual pace of 3.6 per cent (down slightly from 3.7 per cent in March).
Meanwhile,
headline inflation grew by 0.8 per cent in the June quarter
, down from 1.4 per cent in the March quarter.
So, the quarterly rate of growth in wages and inflation is now the same, if for a brief moment.
Dr Chalmers and Mr Burke have picked up on that fact, while noting that the rate of growth in real wages is probably still a while away.
This is the first time in three years that quarterly wages have kept up with inflation
- and much better than the fall of 1.5 per cent in the March quarter 2022," they said.
"While there will be volatility in the next few quarters,
Treasury expects annual real wages to return to growth in early 2024

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has cut a couple of key interest rates today, with more stimulus expected as the country slips into deflation, with a worsening crisis for the real estate sector and property developers. The PBOC lowered its seven-day reverse repo rate, a key source of short-term funding for banks, from 1.9 to 1.8%. It also cut the medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate from 2.65 to 2.5%, in the largest reduction since April 2020 (and we all remember what was happening then). Julian Evans-Pritchard from Capital Economics says it's the fourth round of across-the-board cuts this cycle, with the loan prime rate (LPR) expected to also be cut on Monday. "On its own, rate cuts of this magnitude won't have a big impact," he notes. "They only partially reverse the recent increase in real interest rates due to lower inflation. But the PBOC tends to use changes in policy rates as signalling tool, with the heavy lifting being done by other tools such as adjustments to reserve requirements and bank loan quotas. Today's cut suggests that these tools will be deployed too, consistent with the PBOC's promise of further monetary easing. "But we think this will provide only modest support to credit growth and wider economic activity. "Weak credit demand means that easier availability of credit probably won't drive much of a pick-up in credit growth. Instead, the additional liquidity is like to remain trapped in the banking system, as was the case last year. "Reviving demand would take much larger rate cuts, or regulatory measures to effectively restore confidence in the housing market."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China cuts interest rates in bid to boost struggling economy

children.content: The
People's Bank of China (PBOC)
has cut a couple of key interest rates today, with more stimulus expected as the country slips into deflation, with a worsening crisis for the real estate sector and property developers.
The
PBOC lowered its seven-day reverse repo rate
, a key source of short-term funding for banks, from 1.9 to 1.8%.
It also
cut the medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate from 2.65 to 2.5%, in the largest reduction since April 2020
(and we all remember what was happening then).
Julian Evans-Pritchard from Capital Economics
says it's the fourth round of across-the-board cuts this cycle, with the loan prime rate (LPR) expected to also be cut on Monday.
"On its own, rate cuts of this magnitude won't have a big impact," he notes.

"They only partially reverse the recent increase in real interest rates due to lower inflation. But the PBOC tends to use changes in policy rates as signalling tool, with the heavy lifting being done by other tools such as adjustments to reserve requirements and bank loan quotas. Today's cut suggests that these tools will be deployed too, consistent with the PBOC's promise of further monetary easing.
"But we think this will provide only modest support to credit growth and wider economic activity.

"Weak credit demand means that easier availability of credit probably won't drive much of a pick-up in credit growth. Instead, the additional liquidity is like to remain trapped in the banking system, as was the case last year.
"Reviving demand would take much larger rate cuts, or regulatory measures to effectively restore confidence in the housing market."

image.altText: A fighter jet screams through the air, leaving contrails streaming in its wake.

items.synopsis: The paint for the highly advanced F-35 Lightning II will be applied outside the US for the first time after a government commitment to spend $100m on a facility in Newcastle.

title.children: Australia entrusted with secret paint that makes fighter jet 'nearly invisible'

image.altText: Schoolgirl holding a trophy.

items.synopsis: Matildas star Mary Fowler's World Cup heroics have inspired the next generation of players at her old school in Cairns. But with more people taking up the sport, the challenge will be finding somewhere for them all to play.

title.children: Mary Fowler inspires next generation at her old school in Cairns

image.altText: Exterior shot of an Our Medical centre.

items.synopsis: Patients are being pushed to provide their personal data to a medical provider's app and rewards program in order to access bulk billing from their GP, raising privacy and cost of living concerns from consumer groups.

title.children: 'Unethical and unfair': Patients told to share personal data or lose access to bulk billing

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt is surrounded by reporters with microphones and cameras.

items.synopsis: The celebrity crocodile wrangler is expected to front court in person later this year, where he'll hear more than 20 volumes of evidence amassed against him.

title.children: 'Enormous' brief of evidence against Netflix star Matt Wright includes 150,000 texts

image.altText: man surfing lying down

items.synopsis: Lennox Head surfer Joel Taylor's Australian Para Surfing title has come more than 20 years after his promising career as a professional body boarder was cut short in an instant.

title.children: Surfer's 'life changing' return to waves decades after catastrophic Pipeline wipe out

image.altText: A kitchen worker prepares food at the Golden Sheath Hotel

items.synopsis: Wages growth eases from an annual pace of 3.7 per cent in the March quarter to 3.6 per cent over the year to June, reducing fears of a so-called wage-price spiral.

title.children: Wages growth falls, reducing fears of inflationary spiral

image.altText: Burnt out cars and buildings in Lahaina.

items.synopsis: Search crews are sifting through the rubble of burned-down Maui with the island's governor saying it's likely to find at least 10 more people a day.

title.children: Hawaii wildfires death toll rises with more 'tragic stories' expected

image.altText: Video image captures a fire and emergency workers

items.synopsis: A criminal investigation is opened after a blaze at a Russian auto repair shop kills at least 27 and injures over a 100.

title.children: Fire at Russian car repairs station kills at least 27, injures more than 100

image.altText: A man in a hard hat surveys the damage inside a burnt out Chinese restaurant

items.synopsis: One by one, Chinese restaurants across Perth were being set alight. It was a coordinated and sustained terrorism campaign, but most Australians have never heard of the attacks.

title.children: It was 'a taste of terrorism' in suburban Australia, but most people have never heard of it

image.altText: An immaculate woman wearing a black and white houndstooth top with scalloped collar gazes adoringly at a yellow handbag

items.synopsis: The latest generation of "superfake" handbags can so closely resemble their luxury counterparts that the differences are almost imperceptible to the human eye.

title.children: Indonesia's 'superfake' bags are cheap, handmade, and virtually indistinguishable from the real deal

image.altText: Close up shot of a woman of middle-eastern appearance in sunset light on a beach

items.synopsis: Elahe Yazdani arrived in Australia in 2020 after fleeing Iran, but says giving birth to her son in Wollongong was one of the saddest stories of her life.

title.children: Elahe says her experience in a NSW hospital left her traumatised. Experts say this is typical for refugee women

image.altText: Image of greyhound race with yellow-jacket dog turning into safety rail

items.synopsis: Wagga Wagga's greyhound racing track has been upgraded to improve its safety, but a lead animal rights activist says it isn't enough.

title.children: 'Freak accident' prompts greyhound track upgrades

image.altText: Coral reef with small fish

items.synopsis: Australian scientists have found "incredibly high coral cover" in deeper sections of the Coral Sea relatively undisturbed by fishing and sedimentary run-off.

title.children: Scientists close 'massive gap' in reef knowledge 100m below

image.altText: An elderly man in glasses – paedophile Gerald Ridsdale – sits in front of a blank wall.

items.synopsis: The conviction relates to the indecent assault of a minor – Ridsdale's 72nd known victim – in the late 1980s. The court heard that Ridsdale's health is deteriorating and that he may soon be put into palliative care.

title.children: Notorious paedophile priest Gerald Ridsdale sentenced to eighth prison term

image.altText: Kerr Fowler

items.synopsis: Football fanatics from diverse backgrounds have found inspiration in Matildas players — including Mary Fowler and Sam Kerr, who are "rewriting the possibilities" for women of colour in sport.

title.children: 'This sport is for all': Matildas fans see their culture reflected in players like Sam Kerr and Mary Fowler

image.altText: Donald Trump stands in front of a US flag

items.synopsis: Donald Trump is indicted for the second time, this time by the state of Georgia, for attempting to overturn the 2020 election results. Look back on Tuesday's developments.

title.children: Trump's fourth indictment in five months, second for 2020 election interference — as it happened

image.altText: Rachel Noble posing for a photo in front of an Australian Signals Directorate sign

items.synopsis: Australia's cyber spy agency has been caught up in the KPMG consulting scandal.

title.children: Spy agency caught up in KPMG consulting scandal

image.altText: Flames engulfs a school buidling at night.

items.synopsis: Police are investigating the 'suspicious' fire that has severely damaged a primary school.

title.children: Parent 'gutted' after 'suspicious' fire destroys school buildings in Walgett

image.altText: Composite image of two women and two men.

items.synopsis: Authorities are remaining tight-lipped on the investigation into a suspected mushroom poisoning, after the woman at the centre of the saga gave police a detailed written statement.

title.children: Where cook bought mushrooms for beef Wellington lunch under spotlight as she provides new statement

image.altText: Man surfing in pink and black high vis wetsuit crouched low

items.synopsis: An army veteran is following his son's advice to pursue his passions as a way of coping with the lasting effects of trauma.

title.children: Problems 'dissolve' when veteran Chris Ellicott is searching for his next wave

image.altText: A close-up picture of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews looking thoughtful.

items.synopsis: Victoria's Premier Daniel Andrews has brushed off suggestions of branch stacking linked to the state's Energy Minister Lily D'Ambrosio.

title.children: Daniel Andrews faces questions over allegations dead people had ALP memberships renewed

image.altText: A composite image of Marcus Stewart and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: A prominent Yes campaigner for an Indigenous Voice to Parliament has accused No campaigner and Shadow Indigenous Australians Minister Jacinta Nampijinpa Price of "hate" for First Nations people after she called welcome to country ceremonies "divisive".

title.children: Yes campaigner takes aim at Jacinta Nampijinpa Price over welcome to country stance

image.altText: A man in a business shirt and tie stands on a porch.

items.synopsis: Forensic analysis commissioned by SA Police has found an Adelaide woman who disappeared in Malaysia in 2017 suffered blunt force trauma, with her son saying the family has spent almost $500,000 to find answers.

title.children: 'Something nefarious had occurred': Forensic analysis finds Anna Jenkins suffered blunt force trauma when she died in Malaysia

image.altText: A man looks at the camera with a plain expression

items.synopsis: Police say Tomislav Nemes had been dead for more than a year before his body was discovered during a welfare check.

title.children: Photos of Gold Coast man released as detectives call for help after finding 'mummified' remains

image.altText: An eight year old boy leaning on the left shoulder of his father. Both look a little sombre.

items.synopsis: Andrea Tindiani says ministerial intervention is his last hope as he faces the risk of being forced to leave his son when his bridging visa runs out at the end of the month.

title.children: Italian man implores immigration minister to spare his son the trauma of his dad being deported

image.altText: A close-up of a man with a beard wearing a white shirt

items.synopsis: The former American football player says he was misled into signing documents that placed him under conservatorship instead of adoption and is asking to be paid money made off his story.

title.children: The man behind the Blind Side movie story sues parents for not really adopting him

image.altText: An elderly man in a shawl stands holding the hand of a young muscular man wearing only underpants

items.synopsis: In a series of portraits that range from playful to erotic, artist Gary Lee confronts themes of masculinity and beauty through a lens shaped by his Larrakia, Wardaman, Filipino, Scottish and German origins.

title.children: From mission kid to fashion designer, Larrakia artist Gary Lee's quest to capture masculine beauty
